sen.j: 景行天皇（けいこうてんのう、垂仁天皇17年（紀元前13年）- 景行天皇60年11月7日 (旧暦)（130年12月24日））は、『古事記』『日本書紀』に記される第12代の天皇（在位：景行天皇元年7月11日 (旧暦)（71年8月24日） - 同60年11月7日（130年12月24日））。
sen.e: Emperor Keiko (A.D. 13- December 23, 130) was the twelfth Emperor (Reign: August 22, 71-December 23, 130), who was described in "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters) and "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan).

Emperor Keiko (13 B.C. - December 23, A.D. 130) was the twelfth emperor (reign: August 22, A.D. 71-December 23, A.D. 130), being described in "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters) and "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan).
sen.cmt: A.D. 13を13 B.C. に変更。その他の年号はA.D.と明記。グレゴリア暦に変更
sen.e: Emperor Keiko (13 B.C. - December 23, A.D. 130) was the twelfth emperor (reign: August 22, A.D. 71-December 23, A.D. 130), being described in "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters) and "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan).

sen.j: 和風諡号は大足彦忍代別天皇（おおたらしひこおしろわけのすめらみこと）・大帯日子淤斯呂和氣天皇（古事記）。
sen.e: Japanese-style posthumous name was Otarashihiko oshirowake no Sumeramikoto・Otarashihikooshirowake no sumeramikoto ("Kojiki).
A Japanese-style posthumous name was Otarashihiko oshirowake no Sumeramikoto・Otarashihikooshirowake no sumeramikoto (in Kojiki).
A Japanese-style posthumous name was 大足彦忍代別天皇 (Otarashihiko oshirowake no Sumeramikoto) and it was written as 大帯日子淤斯呂和氣天皇 in Kojiki.
sen.cmt: ・→or読みが同じで漢字が異なるため漢字を補足しました。

sen.j: 風土記には大足日足天皇。
sen.e: His name is written as 大足日足天皇 in fudoki (description of regional climate, culture, etc.)
His name is written as 大足日足天皇 in "Fudoki" (description of regional climate, culture, etc.).
sen.cmt: fudoki は初出なので"Fudoki"と記述。
sen.e: His name is written as 大足日足天皇 in "Fudoki" (description of regional climate, culture, etc.).

sen.j: 風土記には大帯日子天皇、大帯日古天皇、大帯比古天皇。
sen.e: His name is written as Otarashihiko (大帯日子天皇、大帯日古天皇、大帯比古天皇) in fudoki.
sen.cmt: 称号が同じ読みで、異なる漢字で記されていたので漢字もそのまま残しました。
sen.e: His name is written as Otarashihiko (大帯日子天皇、大帯日古天皇、大帯比古天皇) in Fudoki.
His name is written as Otarashihiko (大帯日子天皇、大帯日古天皇、大帯比古天皇) in Fudoki.

sen.j: ヤマトタケル（やまとたけるのみこと）の父。
sen.e: He was the father of Yamatotakeru-no-Mikoto.
He was the father of Yamatotakeru-no-Mikoto.
He was the father of Yamatotakeru-no-Mikoto.

sen.j: 「タラシヒコ」という称号は12代景行、13代成務、14代仲哀の3天皇が持ち、時代が下って7世紀前半に在位したことが確実な34代舒明、35代皇極の両天皇も同じ称号をもつ。
sen.e: Not only the twelfth Emperor Keiko, the thirteenth Emperor Seimu and the fourteenth Emperor Chuai, but also the thirty-fourth Emperor Jomei and the thirty-fifth Emperor Kogyoku, who really existed and were certainly on the throne in the early seventh century, had the title "Tarashihiko."
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Not only the twelfth Emperor Keiko, the thirteenth Emperor Seimu and the fourteenth Emperor Chuai, but also the thirty-fourth Emperor Jomei and the thirty-fifth Emperor Kogyoku, who really existed and were certainly on the throne in the early seventh century, had the title "Tarashihiko."

Not only the twelfth Emperor Keiko, the thirteenth Emperor Seimu and the fourteenth Emperor Chuai, but also the thirty-fourth Emperor Jomei and the thirty-fifth Emperor Kogyoku, who really existed and were certainly on the throne in the early seventh century, had the title "Tarashihiko."

sen.j: このことから、タラシヒコの称号は7世紀前半のものであるとして、12,13,14代の称号は後世の造作と考える説があり、景行天皇の実在性には疑問が出されている。
sen.e: For this reason, there is a theory that the title "Tarashihiko" was used in early seventh century and this title was given to the twelfth to fourteenth Emperors in the future generation, so existence of Emperor Keiko is being questioned.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: For this reason, there is a theory that the title "Tarashihiko" was made and used in the early seventh century, and this title was given to the twelfth to fourteenth Emperors after the seventh century, so existence of Emperor Keiko is being questioned.

For this reason, there is a theory that the title "Tarashihiko" was made and used in the early seventh century, and this title was given to the twelfth to fourteenth Emperors after the seventh century, so existence of Emperor Keiko is being questioned.

sen.j: 記紀の記事は多くが日本武尊（やまとたける）の物語で占められ、残るのは帝紀部分のみになり史実性には疑いが持たれる。
sen.e: Story of Yamato Takeru no Mikoto is described in most part of "Kojiki" and "Nihonshoki", while Teiki (a genealogy of the imperial family) is described in the rest part of them, so their historicity is questionable.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Story of Yamato Takeru no Mikoto is described in most part of Kojiki and Nihonshoki, while Teiki (a genealogy of the imperial family) is described in the rest part of them, so their historicity is questionable.

Story of Yamato Takeru no Mikoto is described in most part of Kojiki and Nihonshoki, while Teiki (a genealogy of the imperial family) is described in the rest part of them, so their historicity is questionable.

sen.j: が、実在を仮定すれば、その年代は4世紀前半か。
sen.e: But if we assume that he really existed, he might be alive in the early fourth century.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: But if we assume that he really existed, he might be alive in the early fourth century.
But if we assume that he really existed, he might be alive in the early fourth century.

sen.j: 都は纒向日代宮（まきむくのひしろのみや、現在の奈良県桜井市穴師か）。
sen.e: Its capital was Makimuku no hishiro no miya (It is considered to be Anashi, Sakurai City, Nara Prefecture.
The capital was Makimuku no hishiro no miya (it is considered to be possibly current Anashi, Sakurai City, Nara Prefecture).
The capital was Makimuku no hishiro no miya (it is considered to be possibly current Anashi, Sakurai City, Nara Prefecture).

sen.j: 晩年の景行天皇58年（128年）に、近江国に行幸、志賀高穴穂宮（しがのたかあなほのみや、現在の滋賀県大津市穴太）に3年間滞在した後、同60年（130年）崩御。
sen.e: In his later years, he visited Omi Province in 128, and after he stayed in Shigatakaanahomiya (present Anou, Otsu City, Shiga Prefecture) for three years, he died in 130.
In his later years, he visited Omi Province in 128, and after he stayed in Shigatakaanahomiya (present Anou, Otsu City, Shiga Prefecture) for three years, he died in 130.
In his later years, he visited Omi Province in 128, and after he stayed in Shigatakaanahomiya (present Anou, Otsu City, Shiga Prefecture) for three years, he died in 130.

sen.j: 年代は『日本書紀』の編年に従って便宜を図った。
sen.e: Date followed the chronology of "Nihonshoki"for reasons of expediency.
Dates described below follow the chronology of Nihonshoki for expediency.
Dates described below follow the chronology of Nihonshoki for expediency.

sen.j: 年（8年）に立太子。
sen.e: In 8, he was formally installed as Crown Prince.
In the year of 8, he was formally installed as Crown Prince.
sen.cmt: In 8を in the year of 8に変更
sen.e: In the year of 8, he was formally installed as Crown Prince.

sen.j: 景行天皇元年（71年）7月に即位、翌年に播磨稲日大郎を皇后に立てる。
sen.e: In August, 71, he ascended the throne and appointed Harima no inabi no ooiratsume to the Empress.
In August, 71, he ascended the throne and appointed Harima no inabi no ooiratsume to the Empress the next year.
In August, 71, he ascended the throne and appointed Harima no inabi no ooiratsume to the Empress the next year.

sen.j: 4年（74年）、美濃国に行幸し、泳宮（くくりのみや、岐阜県可児市）に滞在。
sen.e: In 74, he visited Mino Province and stayed at Kukurinomiya (Kani City, Gifu Prefecture).
In 74, he visited Mino Province and stayed at Kukurinomiya (Kani City, Gifu Prefecture).
In 74, he visited Mino Province and stayed at Kukurinomiya (Kani City, Gifu Prefecture).

sen.j: 八坂入媛を妃とする。
sen.e: He took Yasakairibine as his wife.
He took Yasakairibine as his wife.
He took Yasakairibine as his wife.

sen.j: 九州巡幸
sen.e: Tours Kyushu
Tours to Kyushu
Tours to Kyushu

sen.j: 景行12年（82年）熊襲が背いたので、これを征伐すべく、8月に天皇自ら西下。
sen.e: In 82, since Kumaso (a tribe living in the ancient Kyushu district) disobeyed him, the Emperor himself left for the west to conquer them in August.
In 82, since Kumaso (a tribe living in the ancient Kyushu district) disobeyed him, the Emperor himself left for the west to conquer them in August.
In 82, since Kumaso (a tribe living in the ancient Kyushu district) disobeyed him, the Emperor himself left for the west to conquer them in August.

sen.j: 周防国の娑麼（さば、山口県防府市）で神夏磯媛から賊の情報を得て誅殺した。
sen.e: He got the information about rebels from Kamunatsusohime at saba (the land under direct control of an emperor), Suo Province (Hofu City, Yamaguchi Prefecture) and killed them.
He got the information about rebels from Kamunatsusohime at saba (the land under direct control of an emperor), Suo Province (Hofu City, Yamaguchi Prefecture) and killed them.
He got the information about rebels from Kamunatsusohime at saba (the land under direct control of an emperor), Suo Province (Hofu City, Yamaguchi Prefecture) and killed them.

sen.j: 筑紫（九州）に入り、豊前国京都郡（福岡県行橋市）に行宮（かりみや）を設ける。
sen.e: Then, he entered Chikushi (Kyushu) and set up the temporal shrine in Miyako-gun, Buzen Province (Yukuhashi City, Fukuoka Prefecture).
Then, he entered Chikushi (Kyushu) and set up the temporal shrine in Miyako-gun, Buzen Province (Yukuhashi City, Fukuoka Prefecture).
Then, he entered Chikushi (Kyushu) and set up the temporal shrine in Miyako-gun, Buzen Province (Yukuhashi City, Fukuoka Prefecture).

sen.j: 豊後国の碩田（おおきた）で土蜘蛛を誅して、11月ようやく日向国に入る。
sen.e: After he executed tsuchigumo (those in ancient times who were not subjects of the Yamato court) in Okita, Bungo Province, he finally entered Hyuga Province.
After he executed tsuchigumo (those in ancient times who were not subjects of the Yamato court) in Okita, Bungo Province, he finally entered Hyuga Province.
After he executed tsuchigumo (those in ancient times who were not subjects of the Yamato court) in Okita, Bungo Province, he finally entered Hyuga Province.

sen.j: 熊襲梟帥（くまそたける）をその娘に殺させ、翌年夏に熊襲平定を遂げた。
sen.e: He made the daughter of Kumaso Takeru kill his father, and suppressed Kumaso.
He made a daughter of Kumaso Takeru kill his father, and suppressed Kumaso.
sen.cmt: the daughter を a daughterに変更
sen.e: He made a daughter of Kumaso Takeru kill his father, and suppressed Kumaso.

sen.j: 日向高屋宮（宮崎県西都市か）に留まること6年。
sen.e: He stayed at Hyuga takayanomiya (It is considered to be Nishimoro City, Miyazaki Prefecture) for six years.
He stayed at Hyuga takayanomiya (it is considered possibly to be Nishimoro City, Miyazaki Prefecture) for six years.
sen.cmt: It is を it is に変更。possiblyを挿入
sen.e: He stayed at Hyuga takayanomiya (it is considered possibly to be Nishimoro City, Miyazaki Prefecture) for six years.

sen.j: 18年（88年）3月に都へ向け出立し、熊県（熊本県球磨郡）や葦北（同葦北郡）・高来県（長崎県諫早市）・阿蘇国（熊本県阿蘇郡）・的邑（いくはのむら、福岡県浮羽郡）を巡り、19年（89年）9月に還御した。
sen.e: In April, 88, he left for the capital, and after touring Kuma no agata (Kuma Gun, Kumamoto Prefecture), Ashikita (Ashikita Gun, Kumamoto Prefecture), Takaki no Agata (Isahaya City, Nagasaki Prefecture), Aso no kuni (Aso gun, Kumamoto Prefecture) and Ikunohanomura (Ukiha gun, Fukuoka Prefecture), he returned in September.

In March, 88, he left for the capital, and after touring Kuma no agata (Kuma Gun, Kumamoto Prefecture), Ashikita (Ashikita Gun, Kumamoto Prefecture), Takaki no Agata (Isahaya City, Nagasaki Prefecture), Aso no kuni (Aso gun, Kumamoto Prefecture) and Ikunohanomura (Ukiha gun, Fukuoka Prefecture), he returned in September the next year.
sen.cmt: AprilをMarch(３月）に変更。最後にthe next yearを追加。
sen.e: In March, 88, he left for the capital, and after touring Kuma no agata (Kuma Gun, Kumamoto Prefecture), Ashikita (Ashikita Gun, Kumamoto Prefecture), Takaki no Agata (Isahaya City, Nagasaki Prefecture), Aso no kuni (Aso gun, Kumamoto Prefecture) and Ikunohanomura (Ukiha gun, Fukuoka Prefecture), he returned in September the next year.

sen.j: なお、この天皇親征について、古事記には一切記されていない。
sen.e: Meanwhile, this punitive expedition of the Emperor is not described in "Kojiki" at all.
Meanwhile, this punitive expedition of the Emperor is not described in Kojiki at all.
sen.cmt: Kojikiに付いている引用符を削除
sen.e: Meanwhile, this punitive expedition of the Emperor is not described in Kojiki at all.

sen.j: 25年（95年）7月、武内宿禰を遣わして、北陸・東方諸国を視察させる。
sen.e: In August, 95, he dispatched TAKENOUCHI no Sukune to inspect each region of Hokuriku and Toho.
In July, 95, he dispatched TAKENOUCHI no Sukune to inspect each region of Hokuriku and Toho.
In July, 95, he dispatched TAKENOUCHI no Sukune to inspect each region of Hokuriku and Toho.

tit.e: Activities of Yamato Takeru no Mikoto
Activities of Yamato Takeru no Mikoto
Activities of Yamato Takeru no Mikoto

sen.j: 27年（97年）8月、熊襲が再叛。
sen.e: In August, 97, Kumaso disobeyed the Emperor again.
In August, 97, Kumaso disobeyed the Emperor again.
In August, 97, Kumaso disobeyed the Emperor again.

sen.j: 10月にヤマトタケルを遣わして、熊襲を征討させる。
sen.e: In October, Yamato Takeru no Mikoto was dispatched to conquer Kumaso.
In October, Yamato Takeru no Mikoto was dispatched to conquer Kumaso.
In October, Yamato Takeru no Mikoto was dispatched to conquer Kumaso.

sen.j: 首長の川上梟帥を謀殺し、翌年に復命。
sen.e: Yamato Takeru no Mikoto murdered Kawakami no Takeru and reported on his mission to Emperor Keiko next year.
Yamato Takeru no Mikoto murdered Kawakami no Takeru and reported on his mission to Emperor Keiko next year.
Yamato Takeru no Mikoto murdered Kawakami no Takeru and reported on his mission to Emperor Keiko next year.

sen.j: 40年（110年）10月、日本武尊に蝦夷征討を命じる。
sen.e: In October, 110, Yamato Takeru was ordered to conquer Ezo (northerners) by the Emperor.
In October, 110, Yamato Takeru was ordered to conquer Ezo (northerners) by the Emperor.
In October, 110, Yamato Takeru was ordered to conquer Ezo (northerners) by the Emperor.

sen.j: 尊は途中、伊勢神宮で叔母の倭姫命（やまとひめのみこと）より草薙剣を授かった。
sen.e: On his way, he received the Kusanagi no tsurugi from Yamatohime no mikoto, his aunt, at Ise Jingu Shrine.
On his way, he received the Kusanagi no tsurugi from Yamatohime no mikoto, his aunt, at Ise Jingu Shrine.
On his way, he received the Kusanagi no tsurugi from Yamatohime no mikoto, his aunt, at Ise Jingu Shrine.

sen.j: 陸奥国に入り、戦わずして蝦夷を平定する。
sen.e: He entered Mutsu Province and suppressed Ezo without fighting.
He entered Mutsu Province and suppressed Ezo without fighting.
He entered Mutsu Province and suppressed Ezo without fighting.

sen.j: 日高見国から新治（茨城県真壁郡）・甲斐国酒折宮・信濃国を経て尾張国に戻り、宮簀媛（みやずひめ）と結婚。
sen.e: After he returned to Owari Province from Hitakami no kuni via Nihari (Makabe gun, Ibaragi Prefecture), Sakaorimiya in Kai Province, and Shinano Province, he got married with Miyazu-hime (princess Miyabi).

After he returned to Owari Province from Hitakami no kuni via Nihari (Makabe gun, Ibaragi Prefecture), Sakaorimiya in Kai Province, and Shinano Province, he got married to Miyazu-hime (Princess Miyabi).
sen.cmt: married with を warried to に、princess をPrincessに変更
sen.e: After he returned to Owari Province from Hitakami no kuni via Nihari (Makabe gun, Ibaragi Prefecture), Sakaorimiya in Kai Province, and Shinano Province, he got married to Miyazu-hime (Princess Miyabi).

sen.j: その後近江国に出向くが、伊吹山の荒神に祟られて身体不調になる。
sen.e: After that, he went off to Omi Province, but he became ill by a curse of Kojin (god of a cooking stove) of Mt. Ibuki.
After that, he went off to Omi Province, but he became ill by a curse of Kojin (god of a cooking stove) of Mt. Ibuki.
After that, he went off to Omi Province, but he became ill by a curse of Kojin (god of a cooking stove) of Mt. Ibuki.

sen.j: そのまま伊勢国に入るが、能褒野（のぼの、三重県亀山市）で病篤くなり崩御した（景行43年）。
sen.e: Although he entered Ise Province with that poor physical condition, he became seriously ill and died at Nobono (Kameyama City, Mie Prefecture) in 113.
Although he entered Ise Province with that poor physical condition, he became seriously ill and died at Nobono (Kameyama City, Mie Prefecture) in 113.
Although he entered Ise Province with that poor physical condition, he became seriously ill and died at Nobono (Kameyama City, Mie Prefecture) in 113.

sen.j: ヤマトタケル祭祀に葬られた。
sen.e: He was buried in Yamato Takeru ritual site.
He was buried in Yamato Takeru ritual site.
He was buried in Yamato Takeru ritual site.

sen.j: なお、『古事記』によれば、死の直前に大和を懐かしんで「思国歌（くにしのびうた）」を詠んだとされ、この歌は、太平洋戦争中に東アジア地域へ派遣された兵士の間で大変流行ったという。
sen.e: According to "Kojiki", it is said that he wrote a poem "Kunishinobi uta (a song to remember the country) " with thinking of Yamato shortly before his death, and this poem became very popular among soldiers who were dispatched to East Asia during the Pacific War.

According to Kojiki, it is said that he wrote a poem "Kunishinobi uta" (a song to remember the country) with thinking of Yamato shortly before his death; this poem became very popular among soldiers dispatched to East Asia during the Pacific War.
sen.cmt: Kojikiから引用符を除去。Kunishinobi utaの引用符位置の見直し。また途中にセミコロン（;）を挿入。
sen.e: According to Kojiki, it is said that he wrote a poem "Kunishinobi uta" (a song to remember the country) with thinking of Yamato shortly before his death; this poem became very popular among soldiers dispatched to East Asia during the Pacific War.

sen.j: 倭は 国のまほろば たたなづく 青垣 山隠れる 倭しうるはし（『日本書紀』歌謡三一）
sen.e: Yamato wa kunino mahoroba tatanazuku, aokaki yamagomoreru, yamato shi uruwashi (Great Yamato, of all lands most supreme! Enclosed by ranks of verdant banks on surrounding hills, Great Yamato-unmatched for beauty!) ("Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan) songs and ballads No.31)

Yamato wa kunino mahoroba tatanazuku, aokaki yamagomoreru, yamato shi uruwashi (Great Yamato, of all lands most supreme! Enclosed by ranks of verdant banks on surrounding hills, Great Yamato-unmatched for beauty!) (songs and ballads No.31 of Nihonshoki).
sen.cmt: （『日本書紀』歌謡三一）の表現の見直し
sen.e: Yamato wa kunino mahoroba tatanazuku, aokaki yamagomoreru, yamato shi uruwashi (Great Yamato, of all lands most supreme! Enclosed by ranks of verdant banks on surrounding hills, Great Yamato-unmatched for beauty!) (songs and ballads No.31 of Nihonshoki).

sen.j: 53年（123年）、息子の日本武尊を追慕し、東国巡幸に出る。
sen.e: In 123, Emperor Keiko cherished the memory of Yamato Takeru, his son, and went on tour of Togoku (eastern country, eastern provinces, Kanto provinces).
In 123, Emperor Keiko cherished the memory of Yamato Takeru, his son, and went on a tour of Togoku (eastern country, eastern provinces, Kanto provinces).
In 123, Emperor Keiko cherished the memory of Yamato Takeru, his son, and went on a tour of Togoku (eastern country, eastern provinces, Kanto provinces).

sen.j: 東国から戻って伊勢に滞在し、翌年9月に纒向宮に帰る。
sen.e: After he returned from Togoku, he stayed at Ise and went back to Makimuku no miya in next September.
After he returned from Togoku, he stayed at Ise and went back to Makimuku no miya in September next year.
sen.cmt: in next Septemberを in September next yearに変更
sen.e: After he returned from Togoku, he stayed at Ise and went back to Makimuku no miya in September next year.

sen.j: 58年（128年）、近江国に行幸、高穴穂宮に滞在すること3年。
sen.e: In 128, he visited Omi province and stayed Takaanaho palace for three years.
In 128, he visited Omi province and stayed Takaanaho palace for three years.
In 128, he visited Omi province and stayed Takaanaho palace for three years.
In December, 130, he died at the age of 143.
In November, 130, he died at the age of 143.
In November, 130, he died at the age of 143.

sen.j: 『古事記』では137歳。
sen.e: According to "Kojiki", he died at the age of 137.
According to Kojiki, he died at the age of 137.
According to Kojiki, he died at the age of 137.

sen.j: 山辺道上陵（やまのべのみちのえのみささぎ）に葬られた。
sen.e: He was buried in Yamanobe no michinoeno misasagi.
He was buried in Yamanobe no michinoeno misasagi.
He was buried in Yamanobe no michinoeno misasagi.

sen.j: 『古事記』は「御陵は山邊の道上にあり」と記す。
sen.e: In "kojiki", there is a description that "Emperor Keiko's misasagi is in Yamanobe no michi noe."
In Kojiki, there is a description that "Emperor Keiko's misasagi is in Yamanobe no michi noe."
sen.cmt: In "kojiki" を In Kojiki に変更
sen.e: In Kojiki, there is a description that "Emperor Keiko's misasagi is in Yamanobe no michi noe."

sen.j: 現在、同陵は奈良県天理市渋谷町の渋谷向山古墳（前方後円墳・全長300m）に比定される。
sen.e: Currently, this misasagi is identified with Shibutanimukaiyama-kofun Tomb (large keyhole-shaped tomb mound, 300m total length) in Shibutani cho, Tenri City, Nara Prefecture.
Currently, this misasagi is identified with Shibutanimukaiyama-kofun Tomb (large keyhole-shaped tomb mound, 300m in total length) in Shibutani cho, Tenri City, Nara Prefecture.
sen.cmt: total lengthの前に前置詞(in)を挿入
sen.e: Currently, this misasagi is identified with Shibutanimukaiyama-kofun Tomb (large keyhole-shaped tomb mound, 300m in total length) in Shibutani cho, Tenri City, Nara Prefecture.
